articles.title: A Big Year for the Stock Market
How Antivirus Software Can Be Turned Into a Tool for Spying
articles.content: It has been a secret, long known to intelligence agencies but rarely to consumers, that security software can be a powerful spy tool.

articles.title: Those Seatback Screens on Planes Are Starting to Disappear
articles.content: Airlines have been shrinking their seats for a long time, aiming to reduce the planes’ weight and squeeze in more passengers. But lately, some carriers have been going one step further in redesigning their seats: They’re taking away the seatback screens.

articles.title: Chief of Compass, U.K. Catering Giant, Is Killed in Plane Crash
articles.content: The chief executive of the world’s biggest catering company, which is also one of Britain’s biggest businesses, died on Sunday in a plane crash near Sydney, the Australian police said.

articles.title: Fighting Climate Change, One Laundry Load at a Time
articles.content: COPENHAGEN — A Danish biotechnology company is trying to fight climate change — one laundry load at a time. Its secret weapon: mushrooms like those in a dormant forest outside Copenhagen.

articles.title: Copying iPhone Messages to the Computer
articles.content: Q. I have a long series of text messages on my iPhone between my son and me. Is there a way to copy these from my phone to my computer and save the files in a Microsoft Word document?

articles.title: Start of a New Year of Trading, and Jobs Report From December
articles.content: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:

articles.title: With Disney Deal Looming, Murdoch’s Empire Is Fractured
articles.content: LOS ANGELES — In late summer, Verizon Communications came to Rupert Murdoch with a surprise acquisition offer.

articles.title: How an A.I. ‘Cat-and-Mouse Game’ Generates Believable Fake Photos
articles.content: Researchers in Finland have developed artificial intelligence that can generate images of celebrity look-alikes — and another system that tests how believable they are.

articles.title: Activists’ Guide to 2018: The Best Defense Is a Good Offense
articles.content: If Procter & Gamble were sponsoring a 2018 advertisement for avoiding activists, it might include an in-house remedy for removing corporate stains. Investors seeking new strategies, more dividends, executive changes or board seats aren’t going away. If anything, the siege of P.&G. by Nelson Peltz, whose Trian Partners gained a director’s seat after a 10-month campaign, will embolden others to take up the cause. Resistance isn’t futile, but it needs to be more carefully considered.

articles.title: Logan Paul, YouTube Star, Says Posting Video of Dead Body Was ‘Misguided’
articles.content: A YouTube star with millions of followers apologized on Monday for posting a video that showed a dead body hanging from a tree in a Japanese forest known as a destination for suicide victims.

articles.title: How to Manage Your Career
articles.content: A successful career requires managing the person in the mirror – overcoming your tendencies and habits that can undermine efforts to find happiness at work. Here’s how to do that.

articles.title: Adjusting Twitter’s Sensitivities
articles.content: Q.  I see posts in my Twitter feed that have “sensitive content” labels in place of the message. What counts as sensitive content, and how can I unblock it?

articles.title: TV Content Wars: Too Many Characters Chasing Not Enough Action
articles.content: The golden age of television programming is heading for a grisly finale. Netflix, Amazon, Apple and Hulu are on course to increase their spending on new shows and movies at a faster clip than the growth of the overall video-streaming market. Consolidation among traditional media groups is only adding to the frenzy. Something will have to give.

articles.title: Toasts to the Deals (and Other Winners) of 2017
articles.content: Please take your seats.

articles.title: A Saucy App Knows China’s Taste in News. The Censors Are Worried.
articles.content: HONG KONG — One of the world’s most valuable start-ups got that way by using artificial intelligence to satisfy Chinese internet users’ voracious appetite for news and entertainment. Every day, its smartphone app feeds 120 million people personalized streams of buzzy news stories, videos of dogs frolicking in snow, GIFs of traffic mishaps and listicles such as “The World’s Ugliest Celebrities.”

articles.title: MoneyGram and Ant Financial Call Off Merger, Citing Regulatory Concerns
articles.content: WASHINGTON — United States officials have effectively killed a Chinese company’s $1.2 billion plan to buy MoneyGram, the money transfer company, signaling the Trump administration’s growing skepticism of Chinese purchases of American companies and of broader business ties between the two economic powers.

articles.title: Vice Media Places Two Executives on Leave
articles.content: Vice Media placed its president, Andrew Creighton, and its chief digital officer, Mike Germano, on leave after sexual harassment allegations were reported against them in a New York Times investigation that detailed the treatment of women at the company.

articles.title: Iranian Authorities Block Access to Social Media Tools
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — As protests in Iran stretched into their sixth day on Tuesday, the Iranian authorities continued to restrict access to social media tools that have become key sources of information to antigovernment demonstrators.

articles.title: Made in China: New and Potentially Lifesaving Drugs
articles.content: SHANGHAI — One new drug promises to stop cancer from spreading to other organs. Another would treat blood cancer. A third would use the body’s immune system to kill tumors.

articles.title: Showtime’s ‘The Circus’ Will Go On Without Mark Halperin
articles.content: The Showtime political documentary series “The Circus” is set to return in April, minus its most recognizable star: Mark Halperin, the high-flying journalist whose career was felled last year by allegations of sexual harassment and sexual assault.

articles.title: Researchers Discover Two Major Flaws in the World’s Computers
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Computer security experts have discovered two major security flaws in the microprocessors inside nearly all of the world’s computers.

articles.title: Petrobras of Brazil to Pay $2.95 Billion Over Corruption Scandal
articles.content: Petróleo Brasileiro, Brazil’s state-controlled oil company, said on Wednesday that it had agreed to pay $2.95 billion to settle a shareholder lawsuit in the United States over a corruption scandal that has ensnared dozens of politicians and corporate executives, including two former Brazilian presidents.

articles.title: Russia and Venezuela’s Plan to Sidestep Sanctions: Virtual Currencies
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Russian and Venezuelan officials are hoping virtual currencies can help their countries make an end run around American sanctions.

articles.title: Will 2018 Be the Year of Protectionism? Trump Alone Will Decide
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration will soon face several major trade decisions that will determine whether the White House adopts the type of protectionist barriers that President Trump campaigned on but that were largely absent during his first year in office.

articles.title: Deep Freeze in U.S. Creates Heating Squeeze for Homeowners and Utilities
articles.content: Homeowners, businesses and utilities across much of the United States were keeping a close watch on fuel supplies Wednesday as a record-setting cold snap caused demand for heating oil and natural gas to soar.

articles.title: Car Sales End a 7-Year Upswing, With More Challenges Ahead
articles.content: The auto industry’s long-running sales party has come to an end.

articles.title: Spotify Is Said to Be Going Public in Early 2018
articles.content: Spotify is finally ready to go public.

articles.title: After Dow 25,000, the Party Has to End. But When?
articles.content: In the midst of a long-running bull market that is now reaching momentous proportions, most investors may well have forgotten that just two years ago, during the first five trading days of 2016, the market dropped 6 percent. It was the worst five-day start to a year ever and supposedly a harbinger of bad times.

articles.title: Iranian Hackers: Sophisticated, Frustrated and a Rising Global Threat
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Between breaking into the email accounts of United States government officials, political dissidents and international human rights organizations, Iranian hackers liked to joke about their slow internet service, poor pay and lack of skilled colleagues.

articles.title: ‘Am I Going to Have to Put Mickey Mouse in “American Horror Story”?’
articles.content: PASADENA, Calif. — A top Fox TV executive said she was “shocked” when the deal between 21st Century Fox and the Walt Disney Company was announced. One of Fox’s most prolific hitmakers, Ryan Murphy, said he was “very emotional” and weighing whether he would stick around when his deal with the studio ended later this year.

articles.title: With Sale, Essence Is Once Again a Fully Black-Owned Magazine
articles.content: For the first time in nearly two decades, Essence magazine is once again a fully black-owned publication.

articles.title: Los Angeles Times Newsroom Voting on Whether to Unionize
articles.content: Newsroom employees at The Los Angeles Times began casting ballots Thursday on whether to form a union, in what they believe is the first time journalists have held a union vote in the newspaper’s 136-year history.

articles.title: Competing With the Giants in Race to Build Self-Driving Cars
articles.content: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Before the car can drive without a human, one must first get behind the wheel.

articles.title: Trump Moves to Greatly Expand Offshore Drilling: DealBook Briefing
articles.content: Good Thursday. (We hope that all U.S.-based readers are staying warm.) Here’s what we’re watching:

articles.title: Internet Users in China Expect to Be Tracked. Now, They Want Privacy.
articles.content: SHANGHAI — China’s biggest online payment company offers its hundreds of millions of users a breakdown on their spending each year, showing everything from their environmental impact to their ranking among shoppers in their area. Many spenders — not shy, and occasionally even a bit boastful about their personal finances — in turn share the details on social media.

articles.title: Taking a Look at Linux
articles.content: Q. I hear desktop Linux has gotten to look more like Windows, but can you do everything on Linux that you can do on Windows?

articles.title: Tesla Reports New Setback for Model 3, With Output Lagging
articles.content: Tesla’s first mass-market offering keeps encountering roadblocks.

articles.title: From Mexico to the U.S., a Nafta Tale of Two Truckers
articles.content: Restricted from operating in the United States, most Mexican drivers must hand off their cargo. The Trump administration wants even tighter controls.

articles.title: Uber Shareholders Including Kalanick Loosen Grip With Sales of Stock
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Several of Uber’s early investors and company leaders are beginning to loosen their grip on the ride-hailing company — and are set to reap big riches in the process.

articles.title: U.S. and South Korea Start Trade Talks Amid Rising Tensions
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration and South Korean officials met in Washington on Friday to begin formally renegotiating a free-trade pact that has served as a source of conflict between the two allies. The meeting came at a moment of heightened tension on the Korean Peninsula and unease in the broader region.

articles.title: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Another Huge Security Flaw
articles.content: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

articles.title: Alabama Newspaper Executive Resigns After Admitting He Once Spanked a Reporter
articles.content: The former publisher of The Anniston Star in Alabama resigned on Thursday as chairman of the company that owns the newspaper after admitting that he spanked a reporter in the 1970s.

articles.title: U.S. Job Market’s Strength Is Allowing More to Share in Pay Gains
articles.content: The bustling United States economy is beginning to benefit some American workers who have not gotten a taste of the recovery and have been most in need of relief.

articles.title: Count Bank Overdraft Fees as a Holiday Expense, Too
articles.content: Consumers struggling with holiday spending hangovers may want to reconsider resorting to overdrafts on their checking accounts.

articles.title: Michael Wolff, From Local Media Scourge to National Newsmaker
articles.content: Michael Wolff has, for years, been a prime piranha in the Manhattan media pond, using his caustic columns to tear into his lunchmates at Michael’s, the Midtown mogul canteen, and cutting a memorable figure at star-speckled dinner parties, clad in Charvet ties and shirts by the London haberdashery Browns.

articles.title: Rise of Bitcoin Competitor Ripple Creates Wealth to Rival Zuckerberg
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — The virtual currency boom has gotten so heated that it is throwing the list of the world’s richest people into disarray.

articles.title: Big Tech to Join Legal Fight Against Net Neutrality Repeal
articles.content: WASHINGTON — An industry group that represents the country’s biggest technology companies said on Friday that it planned to join a looming legal fight against the Federal Communications Commission over its repeal of so-called net neutrality rules.

articles.title: Southwest Airlines Settles Suit but Denies Colluding to Keep Ticket Prices High
articles.content: A federal judge has approved a $15 million settlement between Southwest Airlines and members of a class-action lawsuit who allege that the company, along with three other airlines, conspired to limit the number of seats available to customers and keep ticket prices high.

articles.title: Without Naming Trump, Twitter Says It Won’t Block World Leaders
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — For more than a year, Twitter has faced censure for allowing President Trump to use its service to say whatever he wants. And for more than a year, the company has not addressed the criticism definitively.

articles.title: Stock Market’s Rise, Lauded by Trump, Lags the Gains Under Obama
articles.content: President Trump has routinely celebrated, and taken credit for, the stock market’s record-setting climb during his first year in office.

articles.title: Let’s Talk About the Gorilla Channel for One More Day
articles.content: Depending on how you look at it, the Gorilla Channel Incident is either a sign of the imminent collapse of critical thought and public discourse or the first great meme of 2018.

articles.title: Can Sweatcoin, a Hot Fitness App, Keep You Off the Couch?
articles.content: On a recent evening with a windchill of 11 degrees, I made myself put down a book I had been enjoying and go out on the streets of New York instead.

articles.title: Kushner’s Financial Ties to Israel Deepen Even With Mideast Diplomatic Role
articles.content: Last May, Jared Kushner accompanied President Trump, his father-in-law, on the pair’s first diplomatic trip to Israel, part of Mr. Kushner’s White House assignment to achieve peace in the Middle East.

articles.title: India Clings to Cash, Even as Tech Firms Push Digital Money
articles.content: ALIGARH, India — Signs and banners for Paytm, India’s biggest digital payments service, festoon Pooran Singh’s cellphone shop, where people drop in all day to add data or talk time to their prepaid phones.

articles.title: Intel Faces Scrutiny as Questions Swirl Over Chip Security
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — In 1994, Intel faced a public relations crisis over an elusive mathematics glitch that affected the accuracy of calculations made by its popular Pentium computer chips. After insisting that the problem would not affect many people, the company succumbed to public pressure and recalled the chips, costing it $475 million.

articles.title: Apple Investors Warn iPhones and Other Technology May Be Hurting Children
articles.content: A pair of investors who say they hold about $2 billion in Apple stock are pushing the company to do more to protect its youngest users from the effects of digital technology.

articles.title: Toymaker VTech Settles Charges of Violating Child Privacy Law
articles.content: The popular electronic toymaker VTech Electronics agreed to pay $650,000 to settle charges that it had collected digital data on children without parents’ permission and failed to keep that information secure from hackers, the Federal Trade Commission said Monday.

articles.title: You Asked About CES 2018. We Answered.
articles.content: At the giant International Consumer Electronics Show, thousands of tech companies are showcasing some of the hottest new innovations. Our lead consumer technology writer, Brian X. Chen, answered reader questions from the show in Las Vegas.

articles.title: Google Memo Author Sues, Claiming Bias Against White Conservative Men
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — James Damore was  fired from his engineering job at Google last year after he wrote a memo that criticized the company’s diversity efforts and argued that the low number of women in engineering positions was a result of biological differences.

articles.title: With Apple, the Tech Reckoning Gains Momentum: DealBook Briefing
articles.content: Good Monday. Here’s what we’re watching:

articles.title: Resignation of Carrie Gracie, BBC China Editor, Resurfaces Pay Row
articles.content: LONDON — The journalist who resigned as the BBC’s China editor to protest the broadcaster’s gender pay gap said on Monday that she was offered a raise before quitting, but one that still did not bring her to the level of her male peers.

articles.title: Ad Warns Riders About Uber and Lyft, but Some Call It Alarmist
articles.content: Pamela Anderson walks down a city street and uses her cellphone to book a ride. Along the way, she passes a newspaper and street signs that say, “Hollywood Sexual Harassment Scandal Reaches New Lows” and “U.S. Senator Accused of Groping.” When she gets into the car, she sees another sign that says, “Ride-Hail Drivers Suspected of Rape.” The car doors lock, and the driver turns around and suggestively asks, “Shall we?” Just then, “#MeToo” pops up on her phone’s screen.

articles.title: As Trump Appeals to Farmers, Some of His Policies Don’t
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump will head to Tennessee on Monday to appeal to farmers, a key demographic that helped elect him, as he promotes his tax law and previews a new White House strategy to help rural America.

articles.title: Condé Nast Chooses a Digital-First Editor to Run Glamour
articles.content: When Samantha Barry was growing up in Ireland, she and her family would gather around the television to watch the 6 o’clock news. They also told stories around the dinner table and read a number of newspapers and magazines, including Vogue and old issues of Time.

articles.title: H&M Apologizes for ‘Monkey’ Image Featuring Black Child
articles.content: The clothing retailer H&M apologized on Monday for an image appearing in its online store that showed a black child model wearing a hooded sweatshirt that said “coolest monkey in the jungle.” The company removed the image on Monday and said it would also pull the shirt from its stores worldwide.

articles.title: ‘This Is Mine’: Rose McGowan Talks ‘Citizen Rose’
articles.content: PASADENA, Calif. — Get ready for Rose McGowan on the small screen.

articles.title: John Dickerson to Replace Charlie Rose on ‘CBS This Morning’
articles.content: The journalist John Dickerson is a Washington creature to his core: a presidential historian, repository of political trivia and scion of a glamorous Beltway family whose party guests regularly included Kennedys, Johnsons and Reagans.

articles.title: As Electric Cars’ Prospects Brighten, Japan Fears Being Left Behind
articles.content: FUJI, Japan — At a factory near the base of Mount Fuji, workers painstakingly assemble transmissions for some of the world’s top-selling cars. The expensive, complex components, and the workers’ jobs, could be obsolete in a couple of decades.

articles.title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
articles.content: $13.2 MILLION

articles.title: Defending Trump, Roseanne Wants Her Show to Be ‘Realistic’
articles.content: PASADENA, Calif. — Whether the reboot of the sitcom “Roseanne” will be a success for ABC remains an open question, but it will not be lacking in controversy.

articles.title: Finding a Scanner for the Big Jobs
articles.content: Q. I have a lot of documents to scan, and with so many mobile phone apps that can make digital copies, is there any advantage to buying a scanner anymore? Is the quality that much better?

articles.title: Fast-Food Workers Claim Victory in a New York Labor Effort
articles.content: With labor unions seeing their influence wane, more than 200 organizations have sprouted nationwide to help low-wage workers. But nearly all these groups say they are hampered by a lack of dependable funding because, unlike unions, they cannot rely on a steady flow of dues.

articles.title: Tech Backlash Catches Up to Apple
articles.content: The tech backlash has caught up to Apple. The activist hedge fund Jana Partners and the California State Teachers’ Retirement System want Apple to give parents better controls over their children’s iPhones. It’s an unusual issue for an activist, and apps from Facebook and Snap would make better targets.

articles.title: GoPro Needs to Know Its Limits
articles.content: GoPro’s genius discount grows larger. The wearable-camera maker styled itself a media company when it went public in 2014, but even its hardware business is suffering job cuts as sales fall short. Success is even harder than usual when — as at Snap, which fancied itself a camera company — the boss wastes time and resources chasing whims.

articles.title: ‘Media Men’ List Creator Outs Herself, Fearing She Would Be Named

articles.title: Trump Renews Pledge to ‘Take a Strong Look’ at Libel Laws
articles.content: President Trump on Wednesday repeated a pledge to make it easier for people to sue news organizations and publishers for defamation, denouncing the country’s libel laws as a “sham” a day after his personal lawyer filed a lawsuit against a major media outlet, BuzzFeed News.

articles.title: India Extends Hand to Apple and Others by Easing Rules on Foreign Firms
articles.content: MUMBAI, India — India’s central government moved on Wednesday to reinvigorate its sluggish economy by relaxing rules governing foreign investment in industries including retailing and air travel.

articles.title: DealBook Briefing: Buffett Succession Plan Gets Clearer

articles.title: Warren Buffett’s Succession Plan Is Down to Two
articles.content: Who might succeed Warren Buffett became clearer Wednesday.

articles.title: Kodak Last-Gasp Hope: KodakCoin
articles.content: What do you get when you cross the feverish world of cryptocurrencies and a faded industrial giant desperate for a new lease on life? The answer, provided Tuesday by Eastman Kodak, is KodakCoin.

articles.title: Toyota and Mazda Are Said to Pick Alabama for $1.6 Billion Plant
articles.content: Toyota Motor and Mazda Motor are expected to announce on Wednesday that they have chosen a location in northern Alabama, near Huntsville, for the $1.6 billion car plant the Japanese automakers are planning to build together, according to a person familiar with the companies’ plans.

articles.title: 2 Journalists, at Fox and Washington Post, Are Accused of Misconduct
articles.content: Two prominent journalists, one at Fox News and one at The Washington Post, are facing allegations of inappropriate workplace conduct.

articles.title: Adding Gmail Contacts to an iPad
articles.content: Q. I have my account set up in the Mail app, but how do I find my Gmail contacts list on my iPad?

articles.title: He Weaned Himself From Ride-Hailing Apps. Here’s Why.
articles.content: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Mike Isaac, a technology reporter for The Times based in San Francisco, discussed the tech he’s using.

articles.title: Review: Even on the Internet, What’s Old Is New Again
articles.content: It is indisputable that the internet — facilitated by both vast improvements in access and computing power — has had a disruptive impact on not just business but politics and many aspects of our daily lives. Demonstrating precisely what that impact is, however, has been remarkably challenging. Pronouncements on the topic have a tendency to be overblown. “Transformational,” “exponential” and “revolutionary” are increasingly favored adjectives, whether they are applicable or not.

articles.title: Dropbox Is Said to Be Planning to Go Public This Year
articles.content: Silicon Valley has birthed many highly valued and hugely hyped start-ups in recent years, including Uber, Airbnb and Pinterest. Few of those companies have made it out onto the stock market successfully.

articles.title: How Car Companies Decide You’ll Ride a Mustang or Catch a Tiguan
articles.content: When Volkswagen developed a smallish S.U.V. to meet the segment’s growing demand, it faced a challenge: The truck had no name.

articles.title: Walmart’s Bumpy Day: From Wage Increase to Store Closings
articles.content: Walmart, the nation’s largest private employer, waded into the bumpy waters of partisan politics on Thursday, announcing that it will use some of its savings under the new tax bill to provide wage increases, bonuses and expanded benefits to its hourly workers.

articles.title: Marriott to China: We Do Not Support Separatists
articles.content: Marriott International, the hotel chain, wants to be clear on this point: It does not support separatist elements in China.

articles.title: YouTube Drops Online Star Logan Paul From Premium Advertising
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — YouTube said on Wednesday that it had dropped Logan Paul, one of its most popular stars, from its top advertising ranks and had suspended production of a YouTube movie that he was supposed to appear in.

articles.title: China’s Weak Hand in Potential Trade War With U.S.
articles.content: China’s wherewithal to play rough in a trade war with the United States is not as strong as it looks. Beijing is mulling whether to slow or halt purchases of United States Treasuries, Bloomberg reported on Wednesday. The reason may simply be to diversify assets. But as the largest foreign holder of Uncle Sam’s liabilities with $1.2 trillion, China also appears to have some leverage as the Trump administration considers imposing tariffs. Like other retaliatory measures, however, ditching Treasuries would end up costing China.

articles.title: Trump’s ‘America First’ Agenda Is Crashing Davos Party
articles.content: President Trump is crashing the global elite’s ultimate party: He’s planning to attend the World Economic Forum’s annual gathering in Davos this month, the White House confirmed on Tuesday. It’s hard to imagine an audience less receptive to Mr. Trump’s “America First” agenda. Yet, whether he is seeking reconciliation or pitching for strongman status, his mere presence is a rebuke to the elites who got him badly wrong.

articles.title: Ronan Farrow to Develop an Investigative Series for HBO
articles.content: HBO has signed Ronan Farrow to a three-year deal to develop and become the face of a new investigative series, the network announced on Thursday. The deal is set to begin later this year.

articles.title: Inside Uber’s $100,000 Payment to a Hacker, and the Fallout
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — “Hello Joe,” read the November 2016 email from someone identifying himself as “John Doughs.” “I have found a major vulnerability in Uber.”

articles.title: Live Nation Settles Suit With Ticketing Start-Up, Buying Its Assets
articles.content: Two years ago, Songkick, a ticketing start-up that operated out of a loft in Brooklyn, filed an antitrust suit against Live Nation Entertainment, the colossus of the concert business.

articles.title: Farhad’s Week in Tech: A Power Outage at CES, and Facebook Wants to Get ‘Meaningful’
articles.content: Each week, Farhad Manjoo, technology columnist at The New York Times, reviews the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

articles.title: Walmart’s Minor Act of Redistribution
articles.content: Walmart’s pay increase, purportedly inspired by the recent cut in the corporate tax rate, is a little less than real largess. The retailer’s extra spending on hourly wages is just a sliver of what it could save in taxes, though — and a tight labor market is likely to have been a more potent driver.

articles.title: Facebook Is Changing. What Does That Mean for Your News Feed?
articles.content: Facebook has overhauled how it ranks the posts, videos and photos that appear in its users’ News Feeds, introducing major changes on Thursday designed to put what friends and family have to say first.

articles.title: Fiat Chrysler to Spend $1 Billion to Modernize Michigan Plant
articles.content: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles said on Thursday that it planned to spend $1 billion to move production of heavy-duty pickup trucks from Mexico to a factory in Michigan, where it will add 2,500 new jobs as a result.

articles.title: How the Tax Code Rewrite Favors Real Estate Over Art
articles.content: Of the many winners and losers in the overhaul of the tax code, one change makes real estate investors the biggest beneficiaries, while art collectors seem to have drawn the short straw.

articles.title: Holiday Retail Sales Soared, With Biggest Increase Since Recession
articles.content: Shoppers came out in force during the holidays, driven by a strengthening economy, high consumer confidence and rebuilding efforts after a season of natural disasters across the country.

articles.title: Facebook Overhauls News Feed to Focus on What Friends and Family Share
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook has introduced sweeping changes to the kinds of posts, videos and photos that its more than two billion members will see most often, saying on Thursday that it would prioritize what their friends and family share and comment on while de-emphasizing content from publishers and brands.

articles.title: BlackRock: The $6 Trillion Money Manager
articles.content: BlackRock is now a $6 trillion firm.

articles.title: As Labor Pool Shrinks, Prison Time Is Less of a Hiring Hurdle
articles.content: A rapidly tightening labor market is forcing companies across the country to consider workers they once would have turned away. That is providing opportunities to people who have long faced barriers to employment, such as criminal records, disabilities or prolonged bouts of joblessness.

articles.title: Buying a Piece of Bob Marley’s Song Catalog, and His Enduring Legacy
articles.content: When Chris Blackwell, the founder of Island Records, first met a journeyman musician named Bob Marley in 1972, he had a feeling that the young man might find success.

articles.title: In Some Countries, Facebook’s Fiddling Has Magnified Fake News
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — One morning in October, the editors of Página Siete, Bolivia’s third-largest news site, noticed that traffic to their outlet coming from Facebook was plummeting.

articles.title: Big Bets on A.I. Open a New Frontier for Chip Start-Ups, Too
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, tech industry financiers showed little interest in start-up companies that made computer chips.

articles.title: False Missile Warning in Hawaii Adds to Scrutiny of Emergency Alert System
articles.content: WASHINGTON — A false alert sent to cellphones across Hawaii on Saturday warning of an incoming ballistic missile is calling attention to an emergency notification system that government officials at all levels say needs major improvements.

articles.title: Don’t Listen to Washington, Tourist Organizations Try Telling Foreigners
articles.content: Persuading international travelers to visit the United States never used to be difficult. But things have gotten a little more complicated.

articles.title: Detroit Auto Show May Be Celebrating an Era About to End
articles.content: DETROIT — Automakers have reason to celebrate as they gather this week at the Detroit auto show to unveil the new range of brawny trucks, high-tech cars and rugged sport-utility vehicles that will arrive in showrooms in the months ahead.

articles.title: Alexa, We’re Still Trying to Figure Out What to Do With You
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — These days, you can find virtual assistants like Amazon’s Alexa or Google’s Assistant in all sorts of things, from smart speakers and smartphones to washing machines and bathroom mirrors.

articles.title: The Delicate Dance of a Progressive C.E.O. in the Trump Era
articles.content: OKLAHOMA CITY — One of the most formative experiences of J. Clifford Hudson’s life happened about 20 minutes away from the glass-walled office he now occupies as the chief executive of Sonic Drive-In, the burger-and-milkshake chain.

articles.title: The Guardian, Britain’s Left-Wing News Power, Goes Tabloid
articles.content: LONDON — The Guardian, the British newspaper that won a Pulitzer Prize for its coverage of national security leaks in the United States but whose aggressive international expansion has brought heavy losses, switched to a tabloid print format on Monday as part of efforts to cut costs.

articles.title: More Bank Earnings, China’s Growth and Sundance Without Weinstein
articles.content: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:

articles.title: Keeping Up With the Meltdown and Spectre Bugs

articles.content: On Tuesday, the chief executives of the world’s largest public companies will be receiving a letter from one of the most influential investors in the world. And what it says is likely to cause a firestorm in the corner offices of companies everywhere and a debate over social responsibility that stretches from Wall Street to Washington.

articles.title: YouTube Adds More Scrutiny to Top-Tier Videos
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — The decade-plus evolution of YouTube from repository of cat videos and pirated content to potential TV replacement hit a road bump last year when marketers discovered their advertisements were showing up next to extremist videos and other unsavory content.

articles.title: Making Medicaid a Tool for Moral Education May Let Some Die
articles.content: Apparently the plan to Make America Great Again will let some Americans die.

articles.title: G.M. Chief Cautions Trump Administration on Upending Nafta

articles.title: A Push to Make Washington’s Downtown More Livable
articles.content: WASHINGTON — In a 43-square-block portion of the booming central business district, there are just 23 residential units, condos in a row of four late-19th-century townhomes on Jefferson Place, just south of Dupont Circle. It’s a minuscule number compared with the 33 million square feet of office space in the same area.

articles.title: BP to Take $1.7 Billion Charge Over Deepwater Horizon Spill
articles.content: LONDON — The energy giant BP said on Tuesday that it expected to take an additional charge of $1.7 billion in the fourth quarter for claims related to the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster, which killed 11 people and caused the worst oil spill in American history.

articles.title: Chinese Carmaker May Use Fiat Chrysler for Foothold in United States
articles.content: DETROIT — For years, as China emerged as the world’s largest producer of automobiles, American car companies have wondered when a Chinese manufacturer would try to enter the United States market.

articles.title: How Technology Is (and Isn’t) Changing Our Reading Habits
articles.content: How do New York Times journalists use technology in their jobs and in their personal lives? Alexandra Alter, who covers the books industry for The Times, discussed the tech she’s using.

articles.title: ‘Fire and Fury’ May Be Coming to a Screen Near You
articles.content: “Fire and Fury” could be coming to the small screen. Or maybe even the big one.

articles.title: He Leaked a Photo of Rick Perry Hugging a Coal Executive. Then He Lost His Job.
articles.content: As a photographer for the Department of Energy, Simon Edelman regularly attended meetings with Secretary Rick Perry and snapped pictures for official purposes.

articles.title: The Awl and The Hairpin, Eccentric Showcases for Writers, Are Shutting Down
articles.content: For almost a decade, The Awl implored the world to “Be Less Stupid.” There was a “great big internet” out there, the editors cautioned. And by writing intelligently about offbeat topics — from a locket meant to hold “mad money” to a deeply unsatisfying West Elm couch called “the Peggy” — The Awl and its sister sites did their best to live up to the motto.

articles.title: Goldman Sachs Once Looked Invincible. Now It’s Losing Money.

articles.title: Trump Hands Out ‘Fake News Awards,’ Sans the Red Carpet
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump — who gleefully questioned President Barack Obama’s birthplace for years without evidence, long insisted on the guilt of the Central Park Five despite exonerating proof and claimed that millions of illegal ballots cost him the popular vote in 2016 — wanted to have a word with the American public about accuracy in reporting.

articles.title: IBM May Finally Stop Shrinking. But Is It a Turnaround?
articles.content: For five and a half years, nearly the entire tenure of its chief executive, Virginia M. Rometty, IBM has reported a steady erosion of revenue.

articles.content: The Airbus A380 lives on, for now.

articles.content: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau’s acting director, Mick Mulvaney, intensified his efforts this week to curb an agency he has denounced as a regulator run amok. His latest tactic: starve it of cash.

articles.title: When Detroit Muscle Powered a Breakthrough in Heart Surgery
articles.content: As they still do, General Motors cars cruised the streets in the shadow of Detroit’s Harper Hospital in 1952. Above them was the room of Henry Opitek, a cardiac patient who would come to owe his life to the engineers who built those cars — and who helped foster a partnership between the automotive and medical industries that continues today.

articles.title: Amazon HQ2 Choices Are Disappointingly Undisruptive
articles.content: Amazon has disrupted great swaths of the retailing landscape, but it’s choosing not to break the mold with its second headquarters. The e-commerce giant has cut the field of candidates to 20 prime locations to complement its Seattle base, including Atlanta, Dallas and New York. Hundreds of cities hoped Amazon would think outside the box, but a desire for talent and a welcoming environment led it to the usual hot spots.

articles.title: Link Between Underwriting and Trading Is Put to the Test
articles.content: Wall Street is putting a trading axiom to the test. Investment banks often say that underwriting debt and equity issues for companies brings in trading activity, and vice versa. The latest results from the country’s five big players — Bank of America, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley — show that that’s not necessarily the case.

articles.title: Where Amazon May Build Its New Headquarters
articles.content: Amazon’s hunt for a second headquarters, after several months of publicity stunts and dangled perks from cities and regions vying to lure the e-commerce giant, has been narrowed to 20 options from 238 bids.

articles.content: Each Friday, Farhad Manjoo, technology columnist at The New York Times, reviews the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

articles.title: Executive Behind Facebook’s China Charm Campaign Is Out

For aviation fans, the introduction of the “Queen of the Skies” was a triumph of engineering and grace: unprecedented size and speed with spiral-staircase international glamour.

articles.title: Union Is Formed at Los Angeles Times and Publisher Put on Leave

A row of gates guard the entrance to the store, known as Amazon Go, allowing in only people with the store’s smartphone app.

Privately, executives and global leaders who had gathered in Davos continued to worry that the American president could yet indulge his worst instincts — and his penchant for shock on Twitter — to deliver a geopolitical crisis, open up a new front in trade hostilities or offend a vast group of people.

articles.title: Wynn Resorts’ Slide Shows Sexual Misconduct Is a Financial Risk
articles.content: There are some risks that investors can’t price. An allegation of sexual misconduct against a chief executive has now been added to that list. Wynn Resorts shares plunged more than 10 percent on Friday afternoon, wiping $2 billion off the company’s value, after The Wall Street Journal reported that such accusations had been leveled at the company’s founder, chief executive, chairman and biggest shareholder, Steve Wynn. Mr. Wynn promptly dismissed the allegations to Reuters as “preposterous.” The loss of value is a reminder to directors on all company boards that even an unproven suggestion of sexual harassment is now a financial risk.

articles.title: Stephen Wynn, Casino Mogul, Accused of Decades of Sexual Misconduct

A United States trade agency on Friday surprisingly rejected calls by Boeing and the Trump administration to impose duties on Bombardier’s CSeries jet. It shifts the regional-airplane dogfight back to the marketplace, where it belongs, raising the pressure on Boeing to seal a tricky merger with Embraer.

articles.title: A New Shuttle Service, Minus the 1980s Frills
articles.content: The announcement by American Airlines seemed to hark to another era: The airline would be adding shuttle service between New York and Chicago this spring — and serving free beer and wine, no less.

articles.title: Comcast’s Interest in Fox May Force Disney to Raise Its Offer
articles.content: Comcast may be the spoiler in a Disney-Fox show. The cable firm is considering whether to try to thwart the Mouse House’s $52.4 billion purchase of parts of Rupert Murdoch’s empire. The story has many moving parts, and the Walt Disney Company may yet have to raise its game.

articles.title: What the Wells Fargo Crackdown Signals to Corporate America
articles.content: The Federal Reserve imposed penalties on Wells Fargo the other week after a cascade of problems surfaced over the last two years, ranging from opening dummy accounts in the names of customers to forcing borrowers to take out unnecessary automobile insurance.

articles.title: Trump’s Infrastructure Plan Puts Burden on State and Private Money
articles.content: President Trump’s $200 billion plan to rebuild America upends the criteria that have long been used to pick ambitious federal projects, putting little emphasis on how much an infrastructure proposal benefits the public and more on finding private investors and other outside sources of money.

He ate, drank, boarded his flight and got home. And that’s when the trouble started.

articles.title: Trump Tells Lawmakers He’s Mulling Limits on Imported Steel
articles.content: WASHINGTON — President Trump suggested on Tuesday that the United States was likely to impose restrictions on imported metals, reviving the prospects for a continuing investigation whose future has been called into question amid months of pushback and delays.

articles.title: Big Profits Drove a Stock Boom. Did the Economy Pay a Price?

articles.title: Does a Lawsuit Now Help the Weinstein Victims?
articles.content: It seems like a noble pursuit: Eric T. Schneiderman, New York’s attorney general, filed a lawsuit over the weekend against the Weinstein Company over the “toxic” environment it created that allowed its co-founder Harvey Weinstein to harass and abuse dozens of women.

articles.title: Broadcom Now Seeking Fewer of Qualcomm’s Board Seats
articles.content: Broadcom moved the goal posts in its hostile takeover bid for Qualcomm, announcing on Tuesday that it was now seeking only a majority of the chip maker’s board seats in next month’s shareholder vote and raising questions about the future of the deal.

articles.title: YouTube Revamped Its Ad System. AT&T Still Hasn’t Returned.

articles.title: As Work Space, Old Post Offices Have a Timeless Allure
articles.content: The Postal Service moved out of its longtime main post office in downtown Chicago in 1997, but ideas for remaking the Art Deco behemoth never gained traction. The huge building sat vacant, a far cry from the time when workers could sort up to 35 million letters a day there and residents posted mail in its elegant lobby, an airy space with stone floors and decorative panels.

articles.title: As Uber Eyes I.P.O., Its Losses are Slowing. But They’re Still Big.
articles.content: SAN FRANCISCO — After years of losing money, Uber is inching toward profitability.

articles.title: $1.8 Billion in India Bank Fraud Raises Fears of Ripple Effects
articles.content: NEW DELHI — One of India’s largest commercial lenders said on Wednesday that it had detected fraudulent transactions worth $1.77 billion at just one of its branches, raising concerns about the possible impact across the banking sector at a time when the country is struggling to meet its economic growth targets.

articles.title: Blackstone Gives Investors Continuity, Whether They Wanted It or Not
articles.content: Blackstone may think of itself as a disruptive investor, but its approach to succession planning is anything but. The giant alternative-investment manager named the head of its real estate business, Jon Gray, as its day-to-day manager on Tuesday, shunting Tony James into a vice chairman role. Big questions — like whether to remain a partnership — will still sit with the chief executive and co-founder, Steve Schwarzman. Blackstone isn’t run for outsiders’ benefit, and the gradual approach to change shows it.

articles.title: Wall St. Gains as Investors Weigh Inflation and Retail Data

articles.title: Sam’s Club Makes E-Commerce Push With Amazon Prime Competitor

articles.title: Here’s an Idea for Goldman: Buy Bank of New York Mellon
articles.content: There’s a potentially ideal merger partner for the $104 billion Goldman Sachs. The Wall Street firm’s chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, told shareholders on Tuesday that it was already having some success turning around its stumbling fixed-income, currency and commodities trading unit. But buying $56 billion Bank of New York Mellon could be a better fix — if only the asset-management and custody specialist weren’t in a different league.

articles.title: Chipotle Takes a Page, and a C.E.O., From Taco Bell

The chip maker only just wiggled out from under a takeover offer from rival Broadcom. What Qualcomm really needs is less a buyer and more a mediator.

articles.title: Harassment and Tipping in Restaurants: Your Stories

articles.title: ‘Diamonds Are Forever,’ and Made by Machine
articles.content: OXFORDSHIRE, England — In a white industrial building in the rolling hills of the English countryside 16 miles from Oxford, silver machines shaped like spaceships hum inside vast laboratories. They are replicating the extreme pressure and temperatures found deep in the earth’s crust and producing, in mere weeks, what historically nature managed only over billions of years: flawless diamonds.

articles.title: How to Make a Synthetic Diamond
articles.content: Diamonds, among the hardest materials in the world, are formed from millions of years of geological pressure and must be extracted from mines deep in the earth. But stones with the same chemical properties as diamonds can now be made in laboratories. There are two methods of growing synthetic diamonds, and the process can be completed in as little as two weeks. Both options require a diamond seed — a single crystal diamond — from which a larger stone can form.

articles.title: Review: ‘The Book of Why’ Examines the Science of Cause and Effect
articles.content: Everyone knows that the cock’s crowing at dawn does not “cause” the sun to rise. Conversely, we have equal confidence “that flipping a switch will cause a light to turn on or off and that a sultry summer afternoon will cause sales to go up at the local ice cream parlor.” Such intuitions are integral to countless practical and moral judgments that fill our daily lives. And yet, as Prof. Judea Pearl and the science writer Dana Mackenzie note in their illuminating new work, “The Book of Why: The New Science of Cause and Effect,” scientists and statisticians lacked a common language until recently to distinguish between these very different kinds of observation. Indeed, within academia, “causal vocabulary was virtually prohibited for more than half a century.”

articles.content: On a sunny day earlier this month, scores of suited men and women found themselves in a  low-rise building on the outskirts of Florence, Italy, walking by bright hand-painted murals of birds of paradise, wildflowers and dreamy-eyed women wearing turbans, T-shirts and rhinestone-encrusted sunglasses.

articles.title: As Trump Consolidates Power, Democrats Confront a Rebellion in Their Ranks
articles.content: WASHINGTON — The pitched battle looming over the Supreme Court, along with a jolt to the Democratic leadership at the ballot box last Tuesday, is threatening to shatter the already fragile architecture of the Democratic Party, as an activist rebellion on the left and a lurch to the right in Washington propels the party toward a moment of extraordinary conflict and forced reinvention.
